doc.title: Roy Greenslade: Italian law will stop reporting of criminal cases
doc.author: Roy Greenslade
doc.description: Italian journalists are said to be united in anger at a draft law aimed at banning the media from reporting on criminal investigations before they come to trial, despite the fact that most cases take years to reach court

main.p: Italian journalists are said to be united in anger at a draft law aimed at banning the media from reporting on criminal investigations before they come to trial, despite the fact that most cases take years to reach court.

The draft bill outlines penalties of more than €450,000 for publishers and up to €20,000 for journalists who flout the ban. Anyone who records or films without the approval of the person who is being recorded or filmed may also be jailed.
Only "professional journalists" (journalists belonging to the Italian National Order of Journalists) would be allowed to record and film individuals without previous authorisation.

The bill is due to go before Italy's full upper house of parliament next week. It follows soon after newspapers ran leaked transcripts from a graft investigation into public works contracts that have cast a shadow over Silvio Berlusconi's government.

"It is shocking and disturbing that in a democratic country such as Italy the government is proposing a law that is a blatant slap in the face to free journalism and the public's right to know," said the International Press Institute's director David Dadge.
